data.sampled: Yes, it is possible to translate the given statement "More boys have been to Paris than he has" into a formal logical system using propositional logic and quantifiers. The statement can be translated into symbols as follows: ∀x(Boy(x) → (HasBeenToParis(x) ∨ HasNotBeenToParis(x))). Here, the symbol '∀' represents the universal quantifier which means "for all", x represents an arbitrary variable that can take on any value, Boy(x) represents the predicate "is a boy", HasBeenToParis(x) represents the predicate "has been to Paris", and HasNotBeenToParis(x) represents the complementary predicate "has not been to Paris". This translates to saying that for every value of x (i.e., for every person), if x is a boy then either x has been to Paris or x has not been to Paris.
